description: From Middle English pekker, equivalent to peck (“to pick at something in the manner of a bird”) +‎ -er (“forming agent nouns”).

definitionGroups.group: Someone who or something that pecks, striking or piercing in the manner of a bird's beak or bill, particularly:

entries.meaning: (uncommon or regional) Any tool used in a pecking fashion, particularly kinds of hoes or pickaxes.
examples: The women with short peckers or parers,... of a foote long and about fiue inches in breadth: doe onely breake the vpper part of the ground to rayse vp the weedes, grasse, & old stubbes of corne stalkes with their rootes... For their corne,... with a pecker they make a hole, wherein they put foure graines.

entries.meaning: (uncommon) Any machine or machine part moving in a pecking fashion, particularly:
examples: The upper end of the finger o carries a "pecker" p, which consists of a hardened steel piece with a V edge. This pecker is engaged by any one of several steps or notches in a stepped block m carried by the rocking lever l.

entries.meaning: (weaving, obsolete) A picker, a shuttle-driver: the device which moves backwards and forwards in the shuttle-box to drive the shuttle through the warp.
examples: The shuttle... receives its motion from the peckers connected with cords pulled by the pecking lever.

entries.meaning: (telegraphy, historical) A kind of V-shaped telegraphic relay.
examples: Click, click, click, the pecker is at work.

entries.meaning: (US regional, historical) Clipping of pecker mill, a rice mill.
examples: Rice mills, called pecker, cog, and water mills... The first... so called, from the pestle's striking... in the manner of a wood pecker.

entries.meaning: (zoology) A bird, particularly a member of the group including the woodpeckers, flowerpeckers, oxpeckers, and berrypeckers.
examples: The Titmouse, and the Peckers hungry Brood.

entries.meaning: (zoology, usually colloquial or US regional) Clipping of woodpecker (Picidae).
examples: The pecker was esteemed a sacred and divine bird.

entries.meaning: (UK regional, obsolete) An eater, a diner.
(UK regional) A bird's beak or bill.
(chiefly US, regional, slang) A penis; cock, dick.
(UK colloquial, by extension of the sense ‘beak’) A nose.
(UK colloquial, by extension, from the expression ‘keep one's pecker up’) Spirits, nerve, courage.
examples: Mr. King... misstated the fact in saying that he had put a piece of lighted paper to the master's nose while asleep in that house; it was his hot pipe that he applied to the sleeper's nostrils, at the same time crying: Come, old chap, keep your pecker up.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural, derogatory slang) Short for peckerwood ("whitey; white trash")
examples: These peckers know that as well as me.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural, derogatory slang) Short for peckerhead ("dickhead; an aggressive or objectionable idiot").
examples: Goddammit! I give you peckers an inch and you automatically take a mile  […]

entries.meaning: (US) Clipping of pecker head ("an electric motor's junction or terminal connection box, where power cords are connected to the winding leads").
